paths.title: IUI With Partner Sperm
paths.description: Intrauterine insemination using sperm from your partner
paths.suitable_for: Couples with unexplained infertility, mild male factor, or ovulation issues

steps.overview: You'll have an initial consultation with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals, review your medical history, and create a personalized treatment plan. This appointment allows your doctor to understand your situation, explain the iui with partner sperm process, discuss success rates specific to your age and diagnosis, and answer all your questions. You'll also complete required fertility testing to assess your reproductive health and determine the best approach.

You'll complete required infectious disease screening and sign informed consent documents to ensure you understand the treatment process and risks. These screenings protect both you and any future pregnancy, while the consent process ensures you're making fully informed decisions. This is a required step before proceeding with any fertility treatment.
Choose between natural cycle monitoring (tracking your own ovulation) or medicated cycle (using fertility medications). Complete baseline assessment to confirm you are ready to start treatment.

Your clinic tracks your cycle through monitoring appointments (ultrasounds and bloodwork) to determine the optimal timing for your procedure. If using medications, you'll take fertility drugs to stimulate egg development and receive a trigger shot when follicles are mature. This monitoring ensures insemination occurs at exactly the right time for the best chance of success.

On the day of your IUI procedure, your partner provides a fresh sperm sample. The lab then prepares the sperm through a washing and concentration process that separates the healthiest, most motile sperm from seminal fluid. This prepared sperm is then placed directly into your uterus through a thin catheter in a quick, painless procedure, bypassing the cervix and giving sperm a head start toward the egg in your fallopian tube.

Wait approximately two weeks after the IUI, then return for a blood pregnancy test. Your doctor will discuss next steps based on the results, whether continuing treatment or transitioning to prenatal care.

paths.title: IUI With Donor Sperm
paths.description: Intrauterine insemination using donor sperm
paths.suitable_for: Single individuals, same-sex couples, or severe male factor infertility

steps.overview: You'll have an initial consultation with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals, review your medical history, and create a personalized treatment plan. This appointment allows your doctor to understand your situation, explain the iui with donor sperm process, discuss success rates specific to your age and diagnosis, and answer all your questions. You'll also complete required fertility testing to assess your reproductive health and determine the best approach.

You'll complete required infectious disease screening and sign informed consent documents to ensure you understand the treatment process and risks. These screenings protect both you and any future pregnancy, while the consent process ensures you're making fully informed decisions. This is a required step before proceeding with any fertility treatment.

You'll review and select a sperm donor from a donor bank or sperm bank database. You can search by physical characteristics, medical history, education, and other criteria that are important to you. Required counseling helps you understand the emotional and legal aspects of using donor sperm.
Choose between natural cycle monitoring (tracking your own ovulation) or medicated cycle (using fertility medications).

Your clinic tracks your cycle through monitoring appointments (ultrasounds and bloodwork) to determine the optimal timing for your procedure. If using medications, you'll take fertility drugs to stimulate egg development and receive a trigger shot when follicles are mature. This monitoring ensures insemination occurs at exactly the right time for the best chance of success.

On the day of your IUI procedure, donor sperm is thawed from the sperm bank. The lab then prepares the sperm through a washing and concentration process that separates the healthiest, most motile sperm from seminal fluid. This prepared sperm is then placed directly into your uterus through a thin catheter in a quick, painless intrauterine insemination (IUI) procedure, bypassing the cervix and giving sperm a head start toward the egg.

Wait approximately two weeks after the IUI, then return for a blood pregnancy test. Your doctor will discuss next steps based on the results, whether continuing treatment or transitioning to prenatal care.

paths.title: IVF With Own Eggs & Partner Sperm
paths.description: In vitro fertilization using your own eggs and partner sperm, with fertilization method (conventional or ICSI) determined by your doctor based on sperm quality and other factors
paths.suitable_for: Couples with tubal factor, endometriosis, male factor infertility, failed IUI, or unexplained infertility who are using their own fresh eggs and partner sperm

steps.overview: You'll have an initial consultation with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals, review your medical history, and create a personalized treatment plan. This appointment allows your doctor to understand your situation, explain the ivf process, discuss success rates specific to your age and diagnosis, and answer all your questions. You'll also complete required fertility testing to assess your reproductive health and determine the best approach.

You'll complete required infectious disease screening and sign informed consent documents to ensure you understand the treatment process and risks. These screenings protect both you and any future pregnancy, while the consent process ensures you're making fully informed decisions. This is a required step before proceeding with any fertility treatment.
Your doctor selects the best medication protocol for your situation. Complete baseline ultrasound and bloodwork to confirm you are ready to start.

You'll take daily fertility medication injections (gonadotropins) to stimulate your ovaries to produce multiple eggs instead of the single egg released in a natural cycle. Having multiple eggs increases the chances of successful fertilization and embryo development. You'll attend frequent monitoring appointments (~every 2-3 days) where ultrasounds track follicle growth and blood tests measure hormone levels, allowing your doctor to adjust medication dosages for optimal egg development.
When your eggs are mature (follicles reach 17-20mm), you will receive a precisely-timed trigger shot to complete final egg maturation. Egg retrieval is scheduled exactly 35-36 hours later.

Under light sedation, your doctor uses ultrasound guidance to retrieve eggs from your ovaries through a thin needle. The procedure takes 15-30 minutes. You will rest in recovery for 1-2 hours before going home.

Sperm is collected and prepared. Mature eggs are fertilized using conventional IVF (mixing sperm and eggs together) or ICSI (Injection a single sperm into the mature eggs). The next day, the embryologist checks to see how many eggs fertilized successfully.

Fertilized eggs (now embryos) are cultured in the lab for 3-6 days to allow them to develop and reach optimal transfer stage. The embryology team monitors their growth daily and grades their quality to help select the best embryo(s) for transfer. This observation period helps identify which embryos have the best developmental potential. You may also choose genetic testing (PGT) during this time.

Your doctor selects the best quality embryo(s) and transfers it into your uterus using a thin catheter under ultrasound guidance. This is a quick, painless procedure. Any remaining good-quality embryos are frozen for future use.
topic_refs: Fresh Embryo Transfer - Day Five (Blastocyst Stage)

steps.overview: Begin progesterone supplementation to support the uterine lining. Wait 9-14 days after transfer, then return for a blood pregnancy test. If pregnant, you will have early monitoring ultrasounds before graduating to regular prenatal care.

paths.title: IVF With Personal Eggs & Donor Sperm
paths.description: IVF using your own eggs and donor sperm.
paths.suitable_for: Single individuals or couples with severe male factor infertility

steps.overview: You'll have an initial consultation with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals, review your medical history, and create a personalized treatment plan. This appointment allows your doctor to understand your situation, explain the ivf with personal eggs & donor sperm process, discuss success rates specific to your age and diagnosis, and answer all your questions. You'll also complete required fertility testing to assess your reproductive health and determine the best approach.

You'll complete required infectious disease screening and sign informed consent documents to ensure you understand the treatment process and risks. These screenings protect both you and any future pregnancy, while the consent process ensures you're making fully informed decisions. This is a required step before proceeding with any fertility treatment.

You'll review and select a sperm donor from a donor bank or sperm bank database. You can search by physical characteristics, medical history, education, and other criteria that are important to you. Required counseling helps you understand the emotional and legal aspects of using donor sperm.
Your doctor selects the best medication protocol for your situation. Complete baseline ultrasound and bloodwork to confirm you are ready to start. Learn how to administer your fertility medications.

You'll take daily fertility medication injections (gonadotropins) for to stimulate your ovaries to produce multiple eggs instead of the single egg released in a natural cycle. You'll attend frequent monitoring appointments (~every 2-3 days) where ultrasounds track follicle growth and blood tests measure hormone levels, allowing your doctor to adjust medication dosages for optimal egg development.
When your eggs are mature (follicles reach 17-20mm), you will receive a precisely-timed trigger shot to complete final egg maturation. Egg retrieval is scheduled exactly 35-36 hours later.

Under light sedation, your doctor uses ultrasound guidance to retrieve eggs from your ovaries through a thin needle. The procedure takes 15-30 minutes. You will rest in recovery for 1-2 hours before going home.

Donor sperm is thawed and prepared. Mature eggs are fertilized using conventional IVF (mixing sperm and eggs together). The next day, the embryologist checks to see how many eggs fertilized successfully.

Fertilized eggs (now embryos) are cultured in the lab for 3-6 days to allow them to develop and reach optimal transfer stage. The embryology team monitors their growth daily and grades their quality to help select the best embryo(s) for transfer. This observation period helps identify which embryos have the best developmental potential. You may also choose genetic testing (PGT) during this time.

Your doctor selects the best quality embryo(s) and transfers it into your uterus using a thin catheter under ultrasound guidance. This is a quick, painless procedure. Any remaining good-quality embryos are frozen for future use.
topic_refs: Fresh Embryo Transfer - Day Five (Blastocyst Stage)

steps.overview: Begin progesterone supplementation to support the uterine lining. Wait 9-14 days after transfer, then return for a blood pregnancy test. If pregnant, you will have early monitoring ultrasounds before graduating to regular prenatal care.

paths.title: IVF With Donor Eggs
paths.description: IVF using eggs from a donor. ICSI required for frozen eggs.
paths.suitable_for: Advanced maternal age, poor egg quality, diminished ovarian reserve, or genetic concerns

steps.overview: You'll have an initial consultation with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals, review your medical history, and create a personalized treatment plan. This appointment allows your doctor to understand your situation, explain the ivf with donor eggs process, discuss success rates specific to your age and diagnosis, and answer all your questions. You'll also complete required fertility testing to assess your reproductive health and determine the best approach.

You'll complete required infectious disease screening and sign informed consent documents to ensure you understand the treatment process and risks. These screenings protect both you and any future pregnancy, while the consent process ensures you're making fully informed decisions. This is a required step before proceeding with any fertility treatment.

You'll review and select donors eggs from a donor bank. You can search by physical characteristics, medical history, education, and other criteria that are important to you. Required counseling helps you understand the emotional and legal aspects of using donor eggs.

Take estrogen and progesterone medications to prepare your uterine lining for embryo implantation. Your clinic monitors lining thickness through ultrasound to ensure optimal conditions. This happens while your donor undergoes stimulation (fresh) or while eggs are thawed (frozen).
Partner sperm is collected and prepared (or donor sperm is thawed). Once prepared, the donor eggs are fertilized through ICSI. Fertilization is confirmed the following morning.

Donor eggs are fertilized using ICSI. The next day, the embryologist checks fertilization success. Fertilized eggs (now embryos) are then cultured in the lab for 3-6 days. The embryology team monitors their growth daily and grades their quality to help select the best embryo(s) for transfer. You may also choose genetic testing (PGT) during this time.

One or more embryos are transferred to the uterus in a procedure guided by ultrasound. Any remaining quality embryos can be frozen for future use. You'll continue progesterone support medications after transfer.
topic_refs: Fresh Embryo Transfer - Day Five (Blastocyst Stage)

steps.overview: After the two-week wait, you'll return for a blood pregnancy test (beta hCG) to determine if embryo implantation was successful. This blood test is more accurate than home urine tests and can detect pregnancy earlier. If positive, you'll continue medications to support early pregnancy and have follow-up monitoring. If negative, your doctor will discuss next steps and any adjustments for future cycles.

paths.title: Double Donation IVF
paths.description: IVF using both donor eggs and donor sperm - ICSI required for optimal fertilization.
paths.suitable_for: Couples with both partners having fertility issues, same-sex couples, single individuals, or genetic concerns requiring dual donor screening

steps.overview: You'll have an initial consultation with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals, review your medical history, and create a personalized treatment plan. This appointment allows your doctor to understand your situation, explain the double donation ivf process, discuss success rates specific to your age and diagnosis, and answer all your questions. You'll also complete required fertility testing to assess your reproductive health and determine the best approach.
Complete infectious disease screening and sign legal contracts establishing parental rights. Your clinic will coordinate preparation of frozen donor eggs and donor sperm for your cycle.
Review and select both an egg donor and sperm donor.

The carrying partner will take estrogen and progesterone medications to prepare the uterine lining for embryo implantation. The clinic monitors lining thickness through ultrasound to ensure optimal conditions. This happens while donor eggs and sperm are being prepared for fertilization.
Donor eggs are thawed and donor sperm is prepared.

Donor sperm is thawed and prepared. Mature eggs are fertilized using conventional IVF (mixing sperm and eggs together). The next day, the embryologist checks to see how many eggs fertilized successfully.

Fertilized eggs (now embryos) are cultured in the lab for 3-6 days to allow them to develop and reach optimal transfer stage. The embryology team monitors their growth daily and grades their quality to help select the best embryo(s) for transfer. This observation period helps identify which embryos have the best developmental potential. You may also choose genetic testing (PGT) during this time.
Your doctor selects the best quality embryo(s) and transfers it into your uterus using a thin catheter under ultrasound guidance. Any remaining good-quality embryos are frozen for future use.
topic_refs: Fresh Embryo Transfer - Day Five (Blastocyst Stage)

steps.overview: Continue taking progesterone and any other prescribed medications to support potential implantation during the two-week wait. Approximately 9-12 days after embryo transfer, you'll return for a blood pregnancy test (beta hCG). If positive, you'll continue medications to support early pregnancy and have follow-up ultrasounds to confirm heartbeat before graduating to regular prenatal care. If negative, your doctor will discuss next steps, including whether to try another cycle or explore other options.

paths.title: Reciprocal IVF
paths.description: Shared motherhood - one partner provides eggs (biological mother), the other carries pregnancy (gestational mother). Requires cycle synchronization and allows fresh embryo transfer.
paths.suitable_for: Same-sex female couples wanting both partners involved biologically, LGBTQ+ couples seeking shared motherhood experience

steps.overview: You'll have an initial consultation with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals, review your medical history, and create a personalized treatment plan. This appointment allows your doctor to understand your situation, explain the reciprocal ivf process, discuss success rates specific to your age and diagnosis, and answer all your questions. You'll also complete required fertility testing to assess your reproductive health and determine the best approach.

Your doctor selects the best medication protocol for the egg-providing partner and coordinates cycle synchronization. Complete baseline ultrasound and bloodwork to confirm readiness. Learn how to administer fertility medications.

The egg-providing partner takes daily gonadotropin injections to stimulate their ovaries to produce multiple eggs. They attend frequent monitoring appointments (~every 2-3 days) where ultrasounds track follicle growth and blood tests measure hormone levels. Meanwhile, the carrying partner begins endometrial preparation with estrogen.
When your eggs are mature (follicles reach 17-20mm), you will receive a precisely-timed trigger shot to complete final egg maturation. Egg retrieval is scheduled exactly 35-36 hours later.

Under light sedation, your doctor uses ultrasound guidance to retrieve eggs from your ovaries through a thin needle. The procedure takes 15-30 minutes. You will rest in recovery for 1-2 hours before going home.

Donor sperm is collected and prepared. Mature eggs are fertilized using conventional IVF (mixing sperm and eggs together) or ICSI. The next day, the embryologist checks to see how many eggs fertilized successfully.

Fertilized eggs (now embryos) are cultured in the lab for 3-6 days to allow them to develop and reach optimal transfer stage. The embryology team monitors their growth daily and grades their quality to help select the best embryo(s) for transfer. This observation period helps identify which embryos have the best developmental potential. You may also choose genetic testing (PGT) during this time. The carrying partner continues endometrial preparation.

Your doctor selects the best quality embryo(s) and transfers it into the carrying partner's uterus using a thin catheter under ultrasound guidance. This is a quick, painless procedure. Any remaining good-quality embryos are frozen for future use. The carrying partner continues progesterone support.
topic_refs: Fresh Embryo Transfer - Day Five (Blastocyst Stage)

steps.overview: The carrying partner continues progesterone supplementation to support the uterine lining. Wait 9-14 days after transfer, then they return for a blood pregnancy test. If pregnant, they will have early monitoring ultrasounds before graduating to regular prenatal care. Both partners share in the emotional journey of pregnancy.

paths.title: IVF With Gestational Carrier (Surrogacy)
paths.description: Using a surrogate to carry your pregnancy - you create embryos using your eggs (or donor eggs) and partner/donor sperm, then transfer to gestational carrier
paths.suitable_for: Absent/abnormal uterus, medical conditions, or recurrent pregnancy loss

steps.overview: You'll have an initial consultation with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals, review your medical history, and create a personalized treatment plan. This appointment allows your doctor to understand your situation, explain the ivf with gestational carrier (surrogacy) process, discuss success rates specific to your age and diagnosis, and answer all your questions. You'll also complete required fertility testing to assess your reproductive health and determine the best approach.

Complete required infectious disease screening and sign comprehensive legal contracts establishing parental rights. Your clinic coordinates with the gestational carrier to complete their medical and psychological screening.
Your doctor selects the best medication protocol for your situation. Complete baseline ultrasound and bloodwork to confirm you are ready to start. Learn how to administer your fertility medications.

You'll take daily fertility medication injections (gonadotropins) to stimulate your ovaries to produce multiple eggs. You'll attend frequent monitoring appointments (every 2-3 days) where ultrasounds track follicle growth and blood tests measure hormone levels, allowing your doctor to adjust medication dosages for optimal egg development.
Estrogen and progesterone medications prepare the uterine lining for embryo implantation. Clinics monitors lining thickness through ultrasound to ensure optimal conditions.
When your eggs are mature (follicles reach 17-20mm), you will receive a precisely-timed trigger shot to complete final egg maturation. Egg retrieval is scheduled exactly 35-36 hours later.

Under light sedation, your doctor uses ultrasound guidance to retrieve eggs from your ovaries through a thin needle. The procedure takes 15-30 minutes. You will rest in recovery for 1-2 hours before going home.

Partner sperm is collected and prepared (or donor sperm is thawed). Mature eggs are fertilized using conventional IVF or ICSI. The next day, the embryologist checks to see how many eggs fertilized successfully.

Fertilized eggs (now embryos) are cultured in the lab for 3-6 days to allow them to develop. The embryology team monitors their growth daily and grades their quality. You may also choose genetic testing (PGT) during this time. Meanwhile, your gestational carrier prepares their uterine lining with medications.

The doctor selects the best quality embryo(s) and transfers it into the gestational carrier's uterus using a thin catheter under ultrasound guidance. Any remaining good-quality embryos are frozen for future use. The carrier continues progesterone support after transfer.
topic_refs: Fresh Embryo Transfer - Day Five (Blastocyst Stage)

steps.overview: The gestational carrier continues progesterone supplementation. Wait 9-14 days after transfer, then they return for a blood pregnancy test. If pregnant, they will have early monitoring ultrasounds and continue medications to support early pregnancy until graduating to regular prenatal care. You coordinate with your carrier throughout the pregnancy.

paths.title: Sperm Freezing
paths.description: Preserve male fertility by freezing sperm
paths.suitable_for: Before cancer treatment, vasectomy, or advancing age

steps.overview: Cryopreservation of sperm depends on regional restrictions but often requires just a referal from a family doctor
You'll complete required infectious disease screening and sign informed consent documents to ensure you understand the treatment process and risks.
Provide a semen sample through ejaculation in a private collection room. If needed, multiple samples can be collected on different days to maximize the amount of sperm stored.

Your sperm sample is analyzed for count, motility, and morphology to assess quality. The sample is then divided into multiple vials and frozen using a controlled-rate freezing process or vitrification to preserve sperm viability. Frozen sperm is stored in liquid nitrogen tanks at -196°C where it can remain viable indefinitely. You'll complete storage consent forms and arrange for annual storage fees.
When you're ready to use your frozen sperm for fertility treatment, contact the clinic to schedule a consultation to determine the best treatment approach based on your partner's fertility status.

paths.title: Egg Freezing
paths.description: Preserve fertility by freezing unfertilized eggs
paths.suitable_for: Delaying childbearing, before cancer treatment, or medical conditions

steps.overview: You'll have an initial consultation with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals, review your medical history, and create a personalized treatment plan. This appointment allows your doctor to understand your situation, explain the egg freezing process, discuss success rates specific to your age and diagnosis, and answer all your questions. You'll also complete required fertility testing to assess your reproductive health and determine the best approach.

You'll complete required infectious disease screening and sign informed consent documents to ensure you understand the treatment process and risks. These screenings protect both you and any future pregnancy, while the consent process ensures you're making fully informed decisions. This is a required step before proceeding with any fertility treatment.
Your doctor selects the best medication protocol for your situation. Complete baseline ultrasound and bloodwork to confirm you are ready to start.

You'll take daily fertility medication injections (gonadotropins) to stimulate your ovaries to produce multiple eggs instead of the single egg released in a natural cycle. Freezing multiple eggs provides more options for your future family building. You'll attend frequent monitoring appointments (every 2-3 days) where ultrasounds track follicle growth and blood tests measure hormone levels, allowing your doctor to adjust medication dosages for optimal egg development.
When your eggs are mature (follicles reach 17-20mm), you will receive a precisely-timed trigger shot to complete final egg maturation. Egg retrieval is scheduled exactly 35-36 hours later.
Under light sedation, your doctor uses ultrasound guidance to retrieve eggs from your ovaries through a thin needle. The procedure takes 15-30 minutes, followed by 1-2 hours of recovery time.

Eggs are immediately frozen using vitrification, an ultra-rapid freezing technique that prevents ice crystal formation and maximizes egg survival rates. Each egg is carefully frozen and stored in liquid nitrogen at -196°C where they can remain viable for many years. You'll receive a report on how many mature eggs were successfully frozen. Storage consent forms and annual fees ensure your eggs remain safely preserved until you're ready to use them.

You'll complete storage consent forms and arrange payment for ongoing storage fees to maintain your frozen eggs safely. Eggs can remain frozen indefinitely while maintaining viability. When you're ready to use your frozen eggs to try for pregnancy, contact the clinic to schedule a consultation. You'll then go through the egg thawing, fertilization (with partner or donor sperm), and embryo transfer process to attempt pregnancy using your preserved fertility.

paths.title: Embryo Freezing With Partner
paths.description: Create and freeze embryos with partner's sperm
paths.suitable_for: Couples planning to delay pregnancy

steps.overview: You'll have an initial consultation with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals, review your medical history, and create a personalized treatment plan. This appointment allows your doctor to understand your situation, explain the embryo freezing with partner process, discuss success rates specific to your age and diagnosis, and answer all your questions. You'll also complete required fertility testing to assess your reproductive health and determine the best approach.

You'll complete required infectious disease screening and sign informed consent documents to ensure you understand the treatment process and risks. These screenings protect both you and any future pregnancy, while the consent process ensures you're making fully informed decisions. This is a required step before proceeding with any fertility treatment.
Your doctor selects the best medication protocol for your situation. Complete baseline ultrasound and bloodwork to confirm you are ready to start. Learn how to administer your fertility medications.

You'll take daily fertility medication injections (gonadotropins) for 8-12 days to stimulate your ovaries to produce multiple eggs. You'll attend frequent monitoring appointments (every 2-3 days) where ultrasounds track follicle growth and blood tests measure hormone levels.
When your eggs are mature (follicles reach 17-20mm), you will receive a precisely-timed trigger shot to complete final egg maturation. Egg retrieval is scheduled exactly 35-36 hours later.

Under light sedation, your doctor uses ultrasound guidance to retrieve eggs from your ovaries through a thin needle. The procedure takes 15-30 minutes. You will rest in recovery for 1-2 hours before going home.
Partner sperm is collected and prepared. Mature eggs are fertilized using conventional IVF or ICSI. The next day, the embryologist checks to see how many eggs fertilized successfully.

Fertilized eggs (now embryos) are cultured in the lab for 3-6 days to allow them to develop. The embryology team monitors their growth daily and grades their quality. You may also choose genetic testing (PGT) during this time.

Embryos are frozen using vitrification at the zygote, day 3 (cleavage stage), or day 5-6 (blastocyst stage) of development. This ultra-rapid freezing technique preserves embryo quality for future use. You'll complete storage consent forms specifying how long to store embryos, annual storage fees, and what should happen to embryos in various scenarios. Frozen embryos can be stored indefinitely and thawed for future Frozen Embryo Transfer (FET) cycles. When you're ready to attempt pregnancy, contact the clinic to schedule an FET consultation.

paths.title: Embryo Freezing With Donor Sperm
paths.description: Create and freeze embryos using donor sperm
paths.suitable_for: Single individuals wanting embryos for future use

steps.overview: You'll have an initial consultation with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals, review your medical history, and create a personalized treatment plan. This appointment allows your doctor to understand your situation, explain the embryo freezing with donor sperm process, discuss success rates specific to your age and diagnosis, and answer all your questions. You'll also complete required fertility testing to assess your reproductive health and determine the best approach.

You'll complete required infectious disease screening and sign informed consent documents to ensure you understand the treatment process and risks. These screenings protect both you and any future pregnancy, while the consent process ensures you're making fully informed decisions. This is a required step before proceeding with any fertility treatment.
You'll review and select a sperm donor from a donor bank. Required counseling helps you understand the emotional and legal aspects of using donor sperm.
Your doctor selects the best medication protocol for your situation. Complete baseline ultrasound and bloodwork to confirm you are ready to start. Learn how to administer your fertility medications.

You'll take daily fertility medication injections (gonadotropins) for 8-12 days to stimulate your ovaries to produce multiple eggs. You'll attend frequent monitoring appointments (every 2-3 days) where ultrasounds track follicle growth and blood tests measure hormone levels.
When your eggs are mature (follicles reach 17-20mm), you will receive a precisely-timed trigger shot to complete final egg maturation. Egg retrieval is scheduled exactly 35-36 hours later.

Under light sedation, your doctor uses ultrasound guidance to retrieve eggs from your ovaries through a thin needle. The procedure takes 15-30 minutes. You will rest in recovery for 1-2 hours before going home.
Donor sperm is thawed and prepared. Mature eggs are fertilized using conventional IVF or ICSI. The next day, the embryologist checks to see how many eggs fertilized successfully.

Fertilized eggs (now embryos) are cultured in the lab for 3-6 days to allow them to develop. The embryology team monitors their growth daily and grades their quality. You may also choose genetic testing (PGT) during this time.

Embryos are frozen using vitrification at the zygote stage, day 3 (cleavage stage), or day 5-6 (blastocyst stage) of development. This ultra-rapid freezing technique preserves embryo quality for future use. You'll complete storage consent forms specifying how long to store embryos, annual storage fees, and what should happen to embryos in various scenarios. Frozen embryos can be stored indefinitely and thawed for future Frozen Embryo Transfer (FET) cycles. When you're ready to attempt pregnancy, contact the clinic to schedule an FET consultation.

paths.title: Anonymous Embryo Donation Cycle
paths.description: Using pre-created embryos from anonymous donors
paths.suitable_for: Patients requiring donor embryos from anonymous sources

steps.overview: You'll have an initial consultation with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals, review your medical history, and create a personalized treatment plan. This appointment allows your doctor to understand your situation, explain the anonymous embryo donation cycle process, discuss success rates specific to your age and diagnosis, and answer all your questions. You'll also complete required fertility testing to assess your reproductive health and determine the best approach.

Take estrogen and progesterone medications to prepare your uterine lining for embryo implantation. Your clinic monitors lining thickness through ultrasound to ensure optimal conditions for embryo transfer.

Your doctor selects the best quality embryo(s) and transfers it into your uterus using a thin catheter under ultrasound guidance. This is a quick, painless procedure. Any remaining good-quality embryos are frozen for future use.
topic_refs: Fresh Embryo Transfer - Day Five (Blastocyst Stage)

steps.overview: Begin progesterone supplementation to support the uterine lining. Wait 9-14 days after transfer, then return for a blood pregnancy test. If pregnant, you will have early monitoring ultrasounds before graduating to regular prenatal care.

paths.title: Directed Embryo Donation Cycle
paths.description: Using pre-created embryos from known donors
paths.suitable_for: Patients with known embryo donors

steps.overview: You'll have an initial consultation with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals, review your medical history, and create a personalized treatment plan. This appointment allows your doctor to understand your situation, explain the directed embryo donation cycle process, discuss success rates specific to your age and diagnosis, and answer all your questions. You'll also complete required fertility testing to assess your reproductive health and determine the best approach.

Take estrogen and progesterone medications to prepare your uterine lining for embryo implantation. Your clinic monitors lining thickness through ultrasound to ensure optimal conditions for embryo transfer.

Your doctor selects the best quality embryo(s) and transfers it into your uterus using a thin catheter under ultrasound guidance. This is a quick, painless procedure. Any remaining good-quality embryos are frozen for future use.
topic_refs: Fresh Embryo Transfer - Day Five (Blastocyst Stage)

steps.overview: Begin progesterone supplementation to support the uterine lining. Wait 9-14 days after transfer, then return for a blood pregnancy test. If pregnant, you will have early monitoring ultrasounds before graduating to regular prenatal care.

paths.title: Frozen Egg IVF - Partner Sperm with ICSI
paths.description: Comprehensive IVF protocol using previously frozen oocytes with partner sperm and ICSI - includes endometrial preparation, egg thawing, fertilization, and embryo transfer
paths.suitable_for: Patients using their own previously frozen eggs with partner sperm, particularly when egg shell hardening requires ICSI

steps.overview: You'll have an initial consultation with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals, review your medical history, and create a personalized treatment plan. This appointment allows your doctor to understand your situation, explain the frozen egg ivf - partner sperm with icsi process, discuss success rates specific to your age and diagnosis, and answer all your questions. You'll also complete required fertility testing to assess your reproductive health and determine the best approach.

You'll complete required infectious disease screening and sign informed consent documents to ensure you understand the treatment process and risks. These screenings protect both you and any future pregnancy, while the consent process ensures you're making fully informed decisions. This is a required step before proceeding with any fertility treatment.

Your frozen eggs are carefully thawed using a warming protocol. Partner sperm is collected and prepared. Due to zona pellucida hardening from freezing, ICSI (injecting one sperm directly into each egg) is used to fertilize the thawed eggs. The next day, the embryologist checks how many eggs survived thawing and fertilized successfully.

Fertilized eggs (now embryos) are cultured in the lab for 3-6 days to allow them to develop and reach optimal transfer stage. The embryology team monitors their growth daily and grades their quality to help select the best embryo(s) for transfer. This observation period helps identify which embryos have the best developmental potential. You may also choose genetic testing (PGT) during this time.

While your embryos develop, you'll take estrogen and progesterone medications to prepare your uterine lining for embryo implantation. Your clinic monitors lining thickness through ultrasounds to ensure optimal conditions for transfer. The timing is coordinated so your lining is ready when your embryos reach the optimal stage for transfer.

Your doctor selects the best quality embryo(s) and transfers it into your uterus using a thin catheter under ultrasound guidance. This is a quick, painless procedure. Any remaining good-quality embryos are frozen for future use.
topic_refs: Fresh Embryo Transfer - Day Five (Blastocyst Stage)

steps.overview: Continue progesterone supplementation to support the uterine lining. Wait 9-14 days after transfer, then return for a blood pregnancy test. If pregnant, you will have early monitoring ultrasounds before graduating to regular prenatal care.

paths.title: Frozen Egg IVF - Donor Sperm with ICSI
paths.description: Comprehensive IVF protocol using previously frozen oocytes with donor sperm and ICSI - includes donor selection, endometrial preparation, egg thawing, fertilization, and embryo transfer
paths.suitable_for: Single women or patients with male factor infertility using their own previously frozen eggs with donor sperm

steps.overview: You'll have an initial consultation with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals, review your medical history, and create a personalized treatment plan. This appointment allows your doctor to understand your situation, explain the frozen egg ivf - donor sperm with icsi process, discuss success rates specific to your age and diagnosis, and answer all your questions. You'll also complete required fertility testing to assess your reproductive health and determine the best approach.

You'll complete required infectious disease screening and sign informed consent documents to ensure you understand the treatment process and risks. These screenings protect both you and any future pregnancy, while the consent process ensures you're making fully informed decisions. This is a required step before proceeding with any fertility treatment.
You'll review and select a sperm donor from a donor bank. Required counseling helps you understand the emotional and legal aspects of using donor sperm.

Your frozen eggs are carefully thawed using a warming protocol. Donor sperm is thawed and prepared. Due to zona pellucida hardening from freezing, ICSI (injecting one sperm directly into each egg) is used to fertilize the thawed eggs. The next day, the embryologist checks how many eggs survived thawing and fertilized successfully.

Fertilized eggs (now embryos) are cultured in the lab for 3-6 days to allow them to develop and reach optimal transfer stage. The embryology team monitors their growth daily and grades their quality to help select the best embryo(s) for transfer. This observation period helps identify which embryos have the best developmental potential. You may also choose genetic testing (PGT) during this time.

While your embryos develop, you'll take estrogen and progesterone medications to prepare your uterine lining for embryo implantation. Your clinic monitors lining thickness through ultrasounds to ensure optimal conditions for transfer. The timing is coordinated so your lining is ready when your embryos reach the optimal stage for transfer.

Your doctor selects the best quality embryo(s) and transfers it into your uterus using a thin catheter under ultrasound guidance. This is a quick, painless procedure. Any remaining good-quality embryos are frozen for future use.
topic_refs: Fresh Embryo Transfer - Day Five (Blastocyst Stage)

steps.overview: Continue progesterone supplementation to support the uterine lining. Wait 9-14 days after transfer, then return for a blood pregnancy test. If pregnant, you will have early monitoring ultrasounds before graduating to regular prenatal care.

paths.title: Donor Egg IVF with ICSI
paths.description: Comprehensive IVF protocol using previously frozen donor eggs with ICSI fertilization - includes donor selection, recipient preparation, egg thawing, fertilization, and embryo transfer
paths.suitable_for: Patients with diminished ovarian reserve, advanced maternal age, or genetic concerns using donor eggs with ICSI

steps.overview: You'll have an initial consultation with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals, review your medical history, and create a personalized treatment plan. This appointment allows your doctor to understand your situation, explain the donor egg ivf with icsi process, discuss success rates specific to your age and diagnosis, and answer all your questions. You'll also complete required fertility testing to assess your reproductive health and determine the best approach.
Complete infectious disease screening and sign legal contracts establishing parental rights. Your clinic will coordinate preparation of frozen donor eggs for your cycle.
Review and select an egg donor from a donor egg bank database. You can search by physical characteristics, medical history, education, and other criteria that are important to you.

Take estrogen and progesterone medications to prepare your uterine lining for embryo implantation. Your clinic monitors lining thickness through ultrasound to ensure optimal conditions. This happens while donor eggs are being prepared for fertilization.
Sperm is collected and prepared. Mature eggs are fertilized using ICSI (injecting one sperm into each egg). The next day, the embryologist checks to see how many eggs fertilized successfully.

Fertilized eggs (now embryos) are cultured in the lab for 3-6 days to allow them to develop and reach optimal transfer stage. The embryology team monitors their growth daily and grades their quality to help select the best embryo(s) for transfer. This observation period helps identify which embryos have the best developmental potential. You may also choose genetic testing (PGT) during this time.

Your doctor selects the best quality embryo(s) and transfers it into your uterus using a thin catheter under ultrasound guidance. This is a quick, painless procedure. Any remaining good-quality embryos are frozen for future use.

Begin progesterone supplementation to support the uterine lining. Wait 9-14 days after transfer, then return for a blood pregnancy test. If pregnant, you will have early monitoring ultrasounds before graduating to regular prenatal care.

paths.title: Sperm Freezing (Non-Cancer)
paths.description: Preserve your fertility by banking sperm for future use - for medical reasons, before vasectomy, partner travel, or declining sperm quality
paths.suitable_for: Men who want to preserve fertility before medical treatments, vasectomy, military deployment/travel, or those experiencing declining sperm quality

steps.overview: You'll have an initial consultation with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals, review your medical history, and create a personalized treatment plan. This appointment allows your doctor to understand your situation, explain the sperm freezing (non-cancer) process, discuss success rates specific to your age and diagnosis, and answer all your questions. You'll also complete required fertility testing to assess your reproductive health and determine the best approach.

You'll complete required infectious disease screening and sign informed consent documents to ensure you understand the treatment process and risks. These screenings protect both you and any future pregnancy, while the consent process ensures you're making fully informed decisions. This is a required step before proceeding with any fertility treatment.
Provide a semen sample through ejaculation in a private collection room. If needed, multiple samples can be collected on different days to maximize the amount of sperm stored.

Your sperm sample is analyzed for count, motility, and morphology to assess quality. The sample is then divided into multiple vials and frozen using a controlled-rate freezing process or vitrification to preserve sperm viability. Frozen sperm is stored in liquid nitrogen tanks at -196°C where it can remain viable indefinitely. You'll complete storage consent forms and arrange for annual storage fees to keep your samples safely preserved for future use.

You'll complete storage consent forms and arrange payment for ongoing storage fees to maintain your frozen sperm samples safely. Your sperm can remain frozen indefinitely while maintaining viability. When you're ready to use your frozen sperm for fertility treatment (IUI, IVF, or ICI), contact the clinic to schedule a consultation. At that time, your doctor will help you select the best treatment approach based on your partner's fertility status and your family-building goals.

paths.title: Elective Egg Freezing
paths.description: Preserve your fertility by freezing your eggs for future use - whether for career, education, not having found the right partner yet, or personal choice
paths.suitable_for: Women seeking to preserve fertility for social, career, educational, or personal reasons - typically ages 25-37 for optimal outcomes

steps.overview: You'll have an initial consultation with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals, review your medical history, and create a personalized treatment plan. This appointment allows your doctor to understand your situation, explain the elective egg freezing process, discuss success rates specific to your age and diagnosis, and answer all your questions. You'll also complete required fertility testing to assess your reproductive health and determine the best approach.

You'll complete required infectious disease screening and sign informed consent documents to ensure you understand the treatment process and risks. These screenings protect both you and any future pregnancy, while the consent process ensures you're making fully informed decisions. This is a required step before proceeding with any fertility treatment.

You'll take daily fertility medication injections (gonadotropins) for 8-12 days to stimulate your ovaries to produce multiple eggs instead of the single egg released in a natural cycle. Having multiple eggs increases the chances of successful fertilization and embryo development. You'll attend frequent monitoring appointments (every 2-3 days) where ultrasounds track follicle growth and blood tests measure hormone levels, allowing your doctor to adjust medication dosages for optimal egg development.
When your eggs are mature (follicles reach 17-20mm), you will receive a precisely-timed trigger shot to complete final egg maturation. Egg retrieval is scheduled exactly 35-36 hours later.
Under light sedation, your doctor uses ultrasound guidance to retrieve eggs from your ovaries through a thin needle. The procedure takes 15-30 minutes, followed by 1-2 hours of recovery time.

Eggs are immediately frozen using vitrification, an ultra-rapid freezing technique that prevents ice crystal formation and maximizes egg survival rates. Each egg is carefully frozen and stored in liquid nitrogen at -196°C where they can remain viable for many years. You'll receive a report on how many mature eggs were successfully frozen. Storage consent forms and annual fees ensure your eggs remain safely preserved until you're ready to use them.

You'll complete storage consent forms and arrange payment for ongoing storage fees to maintain your frozen eggs safely. Eggs can remain frozen indefinitely while maintaining viability. When you're ready to use your frozen eggs to try for pregnancy, contact the clinic to schedule a consultation. You'll then go through the egg thawing, fertilization (with partner or donor sperm), and embryo transfer process to attempt pregnancy using your preserved fertility.

paths.title: Excess Embryo Freezing
paths.description: Cryopreservation of surplus high-quality embryos from fresh IVF cycle using vitrification protocols for future family building
paths.suitable_for: Couples with multiple good-quality embryos remaining after fresh embryo transfer who want to preserve options for future pregnancies

steps.overview: You'll have an initial consultation with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals, review your medical history, and create a personalized treatment plan. This appointment allows your doctor to understand your situation, explain the excess embryo freezing process, discuss success rates specific to your age and diagnosis, and answer all your questions. You'll also complete required fertility testing to assess your reproductive health and determine the best approach.

You'll complete required infectious disease screening and sign informed consent documents to ensure you understand the treatment process and risks. These screenings protect both you and any future pregnancy, while the consent process ensures you're making fully informed decisions. This is a required step before proceeding with any fertility treatment.

Embryos are frozen using vitrification at either day 3 (cleavage stage) or day 5-6 (blastocyst stage) of development. This ultra-rapid freezing technique preserves embryo quality for future use. You'll complete storage consent forms specifying how long to store embryos, annual storage fees, and what should happen to embryos in various scenarios. Frozen embryos can be stored indefinitely and thawed for future frozen embryo transfer (FET) cycles.

You'll complete storage consent forms and arrange payment for ongoing storage fees to maintain your frozen embryos safely. Embryos can remain frozen indefinitely while maintaining viability. When you're ready to attempt pregnancy with your frozen embryos, contact the clinic to schedule a consultation for a Frozen Embryo Transfer (FET) cycle. Your doctor will create a personalized protocol to prepare your uterine lining, thaw your embryo(s), and perform the transfer procedure.

paths.title: Embryo Freezing for Genetic Testing
paths.description: Freeze-all cycle with embryo biopsy for preimplantation genetic testing (PGT-A, PGT-M, or PGT-SR) requiring cryopreservation while awaiting genetic analysis results
paths.suitable_for: Couples requiring genetic testing on embryos for chromosomal abnormalities, single gene disorders, or structural rearrangements before transfer

steps.overview: You'll have an initial consultation with your fertility specialist to discuss your goals, review your medical history, and create a personalized treatment plan. This appointment allows your doctor to understand your situation, explain the embryo freezing for genetic testing process, discuss success rates specific to your age and diagnosis, and answer all your questions. You'll also complete required fertility testing to assess your reproductive health and determine the best approach.
topic_refs: Preimplantation Genetic Testing for Structural Rearrangements (PGT-SR)

steps.overview: You'll complete required infectious disease screening and sign informed consent documents to ensure you understand the treatment process and risks. These screenings protect both you and any future pregnancy, while the consent process ensures you're making fully informed decisions. This is a required step before proceeding with any fertility treatment.

You'll take daily fertility medication injections (gonadotropins) for 8-12 days to stimulate your ovaries to produce multiple eggs. You'll attend frequent monitoring appointments (every 2-3 days) where ultrasounds track follicle growth and blood tests measure hormone levels, allowing your doctor to adjust medication dosages for optimal egg development.
When your eggs are mature (follicles reach 17-20mm), you will receive a precisely-timed trigger shot to complete final egg maturation. Egg retrieval is scheduled exactly 35-36 hours later.

Under light sedation, your doctor uses ultrasound guidance to retrieve eggs from your ovaries through a thin needle. The procedure takes 15-30 minutes. You will rest in recovery for 1-2 hours before going home.
Partner sperm is collected and prepared. Mature eggs are fertilized using conventional IVF or ICSI. The next day, the embryologist checks to see how many eggs fertilized successfully.

Fertilized eggs (now embryos) are cultured in the lab for 5-6 days until they reach blastocyst stage. The embryology team monitors their growth daily and grades their quality. On day 5 or 6, a few cells are removed from each embryo (trophectoderm biopsy) and sent to a genetics lab for testing. This biopsy does not harm the embryo's ability to develop into a baby.
topic_refs: Preimplantation Genetic Testing for Structural Rearrangements (PGT-SR)

steps.overview: All biopsied embryos are frozen using vitrification immediately after biopsy to preserve their quality while the genetic testing lab analyzes the biopsy samples. This typically takes 1-2 weeks. Freezing allows time for comprehensive genetic analysis without compromising embryo viability. You'll complete storage consent forms and receive results detailing which embryos are genetically normal and suitable for transfer.

You'll complete storage consent forms and arrange payment for ongoing storage fees to maintain your frozen embryos safely. Embryos can remain frozen indefinitely while maintaining viability. When you're ready to attempt pregnancy with your frozen embryos, contact the clinic to schedule a consultation for a Frozen Embryo Transfer (FET) cycle. Your doctor will create a personalized protocol to prepare your uterine lining, thaw your embryo(s), and perform the transfer procedure.

paths.title: Frozen Embryo Transfer (FET) Cycle
paths.description: Transfer previously frozen embryos using your own or a gestational carrier's uterus. This is one of the most common IVF cycle types, used when embryos were frozen from a previous cycle or after genetic testing.
paths.suitable_for: Patients with frozen embryos from a previous IVF cycle, those who did elective freezing ('freeze-all'), or those who completed genetic testing on embryos

steps.overview: Schedule a consultation with your fertility doctor to review your frozen embryos, discuss the transfer plan, and update any medical history. Your doctor will review embryo quality, recommend how many to transfer, and create a personalized medication protocol.

Take prescribed medications (typically estrogen and progesterone) to prepare your uterine lining for embryo implantation. Your clinic will monitor your lining thickness through ultrasounds to ensure optimal conditions for transfer.

Once your uterine lining reaches the ideal thickness (usually 8mm+), your transfer date will be scheduled. You'll receive specific instructions about when to start progesterone support and what to do on transfer day.

On transfer day, the embryology lab will thaw your embryo(s). The transfer procedure is quick and typically painless, similar to a pap smear. The embryo(s) are placed into your uterus using a thin catheter guided by ultrasound.

Continue taking progesterone and any other prescribed medications to support potential implantation. This is called the 'two-week wait' - the time between transfer and your pregnancy test. Follow all medication instructions carefully during this critical time.

Approximately 9-12 days after transfer, you'll have a blood test to check for pregnancy (beta hCG test). If positive, you'll continue medications and have repeat blood tests and ultrasounds. If negative, your doctor will discuss next steps.

paths.title: Using Your Frozen Eggs
paths.description: Ready to use the eggs you previously froze? This pathway guides you through thawing your eggs, fertilization, and transferring the resulting embryos. Whether you froze eggs for medical or elective reasons, this is your roadmap to using them.
paths.suitable_for: Patients who previously froze eggs and are now ready to attempt pregnancy

steps.overview: Schedule a consultation with your fertility doctor to discuss using your frozen eggs. Review your medical history, update any health changes since freezing, and discuss sperm source options. Your doctor will explain success rates based on your age at freezing and number of eggs available.

You'll decide on your sperm source - partner sperm, donor sperm from a bank, or a known donor - as this determines the genetic makeup of your future child. If using partner sperm, your partner will provide a fresh sample or you may already have sperm frozen. If using donor sperm, you'll select a donor and complete necessary legal paperwork. This decision-making step ensures you have the sperm source secured before thawing your precious frozen eggs, as eggs must be used immediately once thawed.

The embryology lab will carefully thaw your frozen eggs. ICSI (intracytoplasmic sperm injection) is typically used to fertilize thawed eggs, as it has higher success rates than conventional fertilization. Your clinic will report how many eggs survived the thaw and were successfully fertilized.

Fertilized eggs (now embryos) will be cultured in the lab for 3-6 days. The embryology team monitors their development and grades them for quality. You may choose to do genetic testing (PGT) on embryos before transfer.

While embryos develop, you'll take medications to prepare your uterine lining. Once ready, one or more embryos will be transferred into your uterus in a quick, usually painless procedure. Any remaining quality embryos can be frozen for future use.

After the two-week wait, you'll return for a blood pregnancy test (beta hCG) to determine if embryo implantation was successful. This blood test is more accurate than home urine tests and can detect pregnancy earlier. If positive, you'll continue medications to support early pregnancy and have follow-up monitoring. If negative, your doctor will discuss next steps and any adjustments for future cycles.

paths.title: Using Your Frozen Sperm
paths.description: Use sperm you previously froze for fertility treatment. This pathway helps you coordinate thawing your frozen sperm with your partner's cycle for IUI or IVF treatment.
paths.suitable_for: Patients with previously frozen sperm who are ready to use it for fertility treatment with a partner or gestational carrier

steps.overview: Schedule a consultation with your fertility doctor to discuss using your frozen sperm. Review your sperm analysis from the time of freezing, discuss treatment options (IUI vs IVF), and create a plan coordinated with your partner's cycle.

Based on your partner's fertility evaluation and your sperm parameters, your doctor will recommend either IUI or IVF to maximize your chances of success with your frozen sperm. IUI may be appropriate if your partner has open fallopian tubes and regular cycles, while IVF is recommended for more complex cases or if sperm count/quality is limited. This assessment ensures you choose the treatment approach that gives you the best chance of pregnancy while making the most of your stored sperm samples.

Your partner will begin cycle monitoring or ovarian stimulation depending on whether you're doing IUI or IVF, as their cycle must be synchronized with the sperm thaw and procedure timing. The clinic tracks their follicle development and coordinates the timing of when to thaw your sperm sample with either their insemination date (IUI) or egg retrieval (IVF). This precise coordination is essential because thawed sperm must be used fresh and cannot be refrozen, so timing is critical for success.

On the day of your partner's IUI or egg retrieval, the lab will thaw your frozen sperm sample. The sperm will be washed and prepared for insemination or fertilization. The lab will assess post-thaw sperm quality and quantity.

For IUI: Prepared sperm is placed directly into your partner's uterus. For IVF: Sperm is used to fertilize eggs in the lab, typically using ICSI if sperm count is limited. Your clinic will guide you through the specific pathway you've chosen.

After the two-week wait, you'll return for a blood pregnancy test (beta hCG) to determine if embryo implantation was successful. This blood test is more accurate than home urine tests and can detect pregnancy earlier. If positive, you'll continue medications to support early pregnancy and have follow-up monitoring. If negative, your doctor will discuss next steps and any adjustments for future cycles.
